docs.lead_paragraph: Mindy Cohen lives a reclusive life marked by fistfuls of painkillers and the drone of daytime television. A former school psychologist who lives in Randolph, Ms. Cohen, 47, has been largely bedbound since 1997, when doctors were forced to remove a portion of her thigh after a liposuction procedure went awry. The unceasing pain, the narcotic-induced fog and the crushing depression, she said, make mundane activities nearly impossible.

headline.main: Behind Walkout by Doctors, Chronic War With Lawyers

docs.abstract: One-day walkout by doctors in New Jersey will focus attention on battle between medical and legal professions over malpractice insurance; action follows similar strikes by doctors in West Virginia and Nevada seeking to limit explosion of sky-high jury awards that saddle doctors with enormous malpractice premiums; Pres Bush is pressing Congress to pass legislation that would limit awards; insurance experts and consumer advocacy groups say focusing on huge awards muddies problem that stems from how insurers invest premiums; consumer groups say rush to cap awards ignores problem of medical negligence and is another symptom of health care system that is deeply flawed; doctors think aggressive lawyers and greedy patients are to blame for spike in premiums and see their battle as noble stand against freewheeling litigation; unlikely coalition of trial lawyers and consumer groups say doctors and insurers are overstating issue of runaway premiums, noting overall number of cases dropped by 7 percent from 1998 to 2002 with payouts rising just 2 percent from 1998 to 2001; two sides disagree about impact of legislation to cap awards on rising premiums; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A study of college students seeking psychological counseling has found that their emotional difficulties are far more complex and more severe than those seen in the past. From 1989 to 2001, the percentage of students treated for depression doubled. So did the percentage of suicidal students, according to the study, conducted at the counseling center at Kansas State University. More than twice the percentage of students were taking some type of psychiatric medication, even though the absolute number of students seen by the center remained stable.

headline.main: More in College Seek Help For Psychological Problems

docs.abstract: Study at Kansas State University finds that students seeking help from its counseling center have emotional difficulties that are far more complex and more severe than those seen in past; percentage of students treated for depression doubled from 1989 to 2001, and more than twice the percentage of students are taking some type of psychiatric medication, even though absolute number of students seen by center remains stable; problems related to stress, anxiety, learning disabilities, family issues, grief and sexual assault have risen, as have more traditional college complaints like trouble in separating from parents, romantic relationships and choice of careers; graph (M)
docs.snippet: A study of college students seeking psychological counseling has found that their emotional difficulties are far more complex and more severe than those seen in the past.    From 1989 to 2001, the percentage of students treated for depression...

docs.lead_paragraph: THEY gather along East Columbia Avenue near Route 46 some of them even before the warming sun comes up -- standing in doorways and in front of stores on these frigid, gray mornings, waiting for contractors to pick them up and take them to jobs in construction, painting or, when the weather dictates, shoveling snow. In the other months they can be found cutting grass or blowing leaves. Eric Carreto, a 22-year-old Guatemalan, is one of thousands of day laborers in the state -- mostly Hispanic men in baseball caps or watch caps pulled down over their ears who emerge from crowded apartments every morning and gather at such places as Morris Street in Morristown or Warren and Blackwell Streets in Dover or Throckmorton Street in Freehold.

headline.main: On the Street, Looking for Work

docs.abstract: Article on growing mistrust and resentment by local businesses and residents to thousands of day laborers, mostly Hispanic men, who congregate each day on New Jersey streets waiting for work; local governments and police departments, noting that anti-loitering ordinances have been struck down in case after case, say there is little they can do; efforts to establish indoor sites where immigrant laborers can gather have been less than successful; state's foreign-born population rose 53 percent between 1990 and 2000; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I hope that Dr. John Baker's medical practice is clearer than his article about the ''insurance crisis'' (Soapbox, Jan. 26). Where is the evidence that lawsuits are the cause of the problem? (Surely we should not accept anecdotal stories in politics and law any more than in medicine.) Nowhere are we told what percentage of the insurance premium is actually used to pay claims (maybe insurance companies lost money in the stock market like so many of us). Instead, we are told to punish the victim of bad medicine. His suggestion for a $250,000 to $500,000 ceiling for pain and suffering that may last a lifetime is better left to a jury of our peers. MARTIN LEVITT Rockaway

headline.main: Other Opinions About the Medical Crisis

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration, whose Medicare ideas are getting a chilly reception on Capitol Hill, is learning the same hard political truths about health policy that the Clinton administration learned a decade ago. Among them: the details are important and often deadly. For all the cheerful sound bites -- like President Bush's promise of choice and President Clinton's promise of ''health care that's always there'' -- sooner or later people will find out how a health care proposal actually works, and the trade-offs it involves.

headline.main: Political Memo; Bush, Like Clinton, Learns Perils of Health Policy

docs.abstract: Bush administration, whose Medicare ideas are getting cool reception from Congress, is learning same hard political truths about health policy that Clinton administration learned in early 1990's, the most important being that broad generalities of plan must be translated into details about how proposal will actually work and trade-offs it will involve; another lesson is that any hint of coercing people into health maintenance organizations -- and using carrot of drug benefits to entice them - is guaranteed to create uproar; yet another is that lawmakers from states with significant rural populations are suspicious of a plan that seems to rely on HMO's or other private health plans to deliver drug benefits (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THESE may be the faces of the rescued. Virtually no one in Africa admits being H.I.V.-positive. But everyone knows someone who has died young. Very few even ask for tests, because the result, as President Bush noted in his State of the Union address last week, is so often a death sentence: Yes, you have AIDS. We have no drugs. We're sorry. Go home and die. Almost 20 years after scientists first realized AIDS was a threat in Africa, Mr. Bush announced that the United States would try to halt this chain of misery. In seeking up to $15 billion over five years to pay for AIDS treatment in Africa and the Caribbean, he was taking a new step in reversing American policy. The first breakthrough came in 1999, when the Clinton administration reversed itself and stopped threatening trade sanctions against African nations that tried to import inexpensive generic AIDS drugs, whose general availability drug manufacturers had opposed.

headline.main: Where AIDS Stalks, Everyone Lives in Fear

docs.abstract: Photos of Africans who comment on scourge of AIDS

docs.lead_paragraph: Two dozen surgeons walked off the job in West Virginia on New Year's Day to protest the costs of medical malpractice insurance and reduced reimbursement rates. After effectively paralyzing emergency rooms at Wheeling Hospital, Ohio Valley Medical Center and Weirton Medical Center for almost two weeks, most of the surgeons returned to work on Jan. 13, after legislation was introduced to amend malpractice liability language and lower the cap on damage awards for pain and suffering. That bill, which has passed the House of Delegates, is now under review in the West Virginia Senate. Many surgeons have said that if it fails, they'll walk out again -- or simply look for jobs in other states. Their protest has already inspired some of their peers: surgeons in coastal Mississippi have just walked out, and doctors in New Jersey are planning a slow-down this month. Loch Adamson Stephen Alatis, orthopedic surgeon, Weirton: ''I was born and raised in Weirton. Whenever I spoke to other doctors, they kind of smirked at the fact that I was actually back in West Virginia. They thought I was an idiot for coming back.'' Dante Marra, orthopedic surgeon, Wheeling: ''Everything is in my wife's name. I can't even participate in the American dream of owning a home, because it would be fair game for a trial attorney.'' Eduardo Esper, cardiothoracic surgeon, Wheeling: ''We're not prepared, having spent all night with a patient, for that patient to come back and sue us. And the majority of the time, those suits are promoted by lawyers that I believe are greedy.'' Patrick Rosario, cardiothoracic surgeon, Weirton: ''Nobody lives forever. Once you get that concept into the system -- that and that just because somebody gets a bad result doesn't mean that there should be a lawsuit -- it'll be great.'' Ahmad Rahbar, cardiothoracic surgeon, Wheeling: ''I did not take the Hippocratic oath to practice medicine in this environment. I am always looking at the patient as sort of a potential enemy -- and that is not a healthy situation to be in.'' Robert Zaleski, orthopedic surgeon, Wheeling: ''I made a decision to come back to my hometown, Wheeling, in 1980 and be part of my roots. But I feel like I am just on the brink of having to uproot my family and move out of state.''

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 2-2-03: TESTIMONY

docs.lead_paragraph: Who hasn't had a problem at one point or another with managed care? Half of all privately insured adults under the age of 65 have had disputes with their health plans in the last year, according to the most recent survey, published in 2001, by the Kaiser Family Foundation and Harvard University School of Public Health. Navigating the dispute resolution process, though, can be overwhelming, especially for people who are also dealing with a medical problem.

headline.main: A Guide to Navigate Managed Care Fights

docs.abstract: Kaiser Family Foundation and Consumers Union publish state-specific guidelines on their Web sites to help people resolve disputes with their health plans (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Hitler industry has marched effortlessly into the 21st century, with a new round of movies, documentaries and books. But this isn't your father's Hitler. The previous generation was fixated on military strategy, the corruption of power, the nature of evil. Now there's a new emphasis on psychology and aesthetics, youthful disappointments and artistic frustration. Was Hitler gay, or simply misunderstood? Or maybe it was something in his childhood. In the recent independent film ''Max,'' the future Führer appears as a young aspiring artist, more obsessed with his painting career than his embryonic political ambitions. HBO recently announced production of a documentary based on ''The Hidden Hitler,'' a widely disputed 2001 biography that claims Hitler was a repressed homosexual. CBS has announced its intention to produce a mini-series about Hitler's boyhood (not to be confused with the Hitler Youth).

headline.main: Is a Demon Humanized No Longer A Demon?

docs.abstract: Article on recent and upcoming films on Adolf Hitler that attempt to humanize dictator, focuses on documentary Blind Spot: Hitler's Secretary, which consists entirely of interviews with Traudl Junge, one of Hitler's private secretaries to whom he dictated his last will; says many viewers are repelled by films that attempt to humanize Hitler; photos (M)
